author: Gr1zlii
review: Did you ever hear the tragedy of Darth Plagueis The Wise? I thought not. It’s not a story the Jedi would tell you. It’s a Sith legend. Darth Plagueis was a Dark Lord of the Sith, so powerful and so wise he could use the Force to influence the midichlorians to create life… He had such a knowledge of the dark side that he could even keep the ones he cared about from dying. The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural. He became so powerful… the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.

author: ipodplayer777
review: So far:+ The graphics look great. + I actually like the mouse controls, I love being able to use my mouse to look around in a lego game. + Combat is fun, if not a little easy. + I like the upgrades. HOWEVER- The game feels scatterbrained. The cutscenes are longer than the gameplay. Blowing up the trade federation ship took all of a minute. There's too many hubs, the traveling system is very confusing at first. There's no prompts on how to unlock any of the characters. - It doesn't run well on my 3070ti. It's thermal throttling everytime there's more than 5 enemies. Very surprised. - The Remote-Play is terrible. I've been playing it with a friend and even though I'm using Keyboard and Mouse, he's always player 1 with a controller. The controls for it are glitchy. There's no Anakin vs Obi-Wan PvP Duel, player 2 simply spectates as C3PO. I would've much preferred an online co-op, I mean it's been 15 years. I'll keep updating this as I play more. It's ambitious, that's for sure. So far, a 6/10.

author: 「 R3STRIKT3D 」
review: Remember playing the lego games as a kid? This captures that magic once again, but also makes it feel fresh and entertaining.The only downside for me is no online co-op, however that's not a deal breaker for me! TT Games definitely used the extra time to make something special

author: XiroxisTheBeard
review: I'm a big fan of the LEGO game genre, with a few of them being in the super narrow list of "Games I've 100%'d." I'm also a fan of (most of) the Star Wars series, playing past games like LEGO The Force Awakens and the original Star Wars LEGO games, so it seemed right to hop into this one. That being said, something just didn't feel right about it.I started with Episode I and it felt rushed. Key moments of dialogue/story were removed or, honestly what may be worse, changed. I've experienced LEGO games doing this in the past, but it didn't feel as egregious as this one. Rushing along the story and prioritizing the collection of items rather than the enjoyment of the story and world around me didn't sit well. The HUD was entirely too crowded and busy, including the menu screen for upgrades and such. The pacing in LEGO LotR or The Force Awakens felt much better, where collecting was the secondary objective to enjoying the story play out. LEGO Marvel (the first one) and LotR nailed the idea of an open world with things to do while having a cool, silly and engaging story. In the Episode I track, I felt overwhelmed by the amount that I could do in the Hub locations without being able to do much with them (because of Free Play lock, which is normal for these games), while at the same time I was underwhelmed by the Story missions' substance. Trying to fit NINE movies into one game is quite a task, and it may just be too much content crammed into one space. I'd much prefer Quality over Quantity.Bug-wise, the cut-scenes were a bit jumpy and climbing up ladders was a nightmare.As a positive, the game looks gorgeous, from the locations, to the player models having dirt on them. Wonderful work on that front.Overall, I love LEGO, LEGO games, and Star Wars, but this iteration doesn't grab me. It feels off, less engaging and, unfortunately, not very fun.

author: Magic_0ne
review: So remember how FNAF security breach was just fetch quest like "go here! Now go here! Now come back! Now do that again but this time in a different order!" For me that wasn't fun at all. I didn't play it but man it looked tedious...especially with all the bugs.This game is basically that but it doesn't have the bugs so it's slightly more bearable. This game is NOT lego star wars. It's a different game with a lego star wars skin slapped on it. The levels themselves are severely lacking, very few mechanics, boss fight mechanics are reused over and over again. And the game makes you go from open to open world to open world in between levels to waste your time so you don't realize just how short the levels are. For example the very first level you're on a space ship and...oh you just hover over the trade ship and press a button...why is this here? Anyways after that you're in the meeting room just like the old lego star wars...oh wait that's a open world/hub world...ok now the level started and you're in jar jar's home...oh wait that's another open world...ok now you have to go to the chief and tal- WAIT WAIT HOLD UP FOLLOW JAR JAR while he moves ever so slowly to the chief THEN YOU CAN TALK TO HIM! Then you have to walk to the ship on the opposite site of the hub world on the lowest level. THEN the first level finally starts...and all you do is press 2 buttons while a giant fish chases you. One to shoot and one to dodge...that's it. literally a 5m level and you had to spend like 20 navigating the stupid ass hub worlds. What the actual ♥♥♥♥? This gameplay persist throughout most of the game...1) Open world is not fun and it's dryOk that's fine because the open world areas are fun right? No...not really. It's basically just an open world with collectibles and NPCs you can SOMETIMES talk to if you have the right characters that can understand the language because that's a mechanic...cool. They do have enemies but once you defeat enemies in the open world zone they NEVER EVER respawn unless you create a new save file. YEAH!! If you want an open world Lego game there's other options that do it better.2) Player 2 experience is awfulAlso do NOT play this with a 2nd player...the fight with Anakin is literally just player 1 most of the time and will occasionally switch to player 2 as R2D2 so they can press a button to activate a panel...THATS IT! Player 2 is highly disregarded a LOT and that kind of thing happens many times.3) Controller support issuesThat's once you're playing the game that is. First this game lies about "full controller support" as it doesn't support the PS controller and while it does work it gives the Xbox prompts which is mildly annoying. I had to use a 3rd party software to get it to give me PlayStation prompts. However then the share/select button that closes the holo menu didn't work so I'd have to press circle 3-4 times to close out of it...so I fiddled with the software for like 2+ hours and couldn't figure it out because the button worked outside of the game but in game refused to recognize the button press. Ok...whatever R3 isn't being used...here it is "open holo menu" let me just rebind that...surely it will rebind it for closing it too right? right!?4) Horrible button remapping with very little options...you can probably guess...it didn't. Because whoever was in charge of button remapping let me just say...they are either really stupid or they rushed that crap together in a single day. So I couldn't rebind it and also most of the button remapping option just rebind the button for like 10+ different actions instead of just one...like HUH!?! THIS GAME IS 50 BUCKS AND YOU- naaah. I had to deal with so many controller issues on a 50 dollar game that has "Full controller support" and once I played the game I literally got through episode I in less than an hour with only 10m being ACTUAL levels and the rest was just going from point A to B in the open world. Which lacked any action or anything interesting.Like I said before this is some other game using the Lego Star Wars brand as a skin. If you want nostalgia sure it works but gameplay wise it's not the same and when you beat an episode rather than feeling satisfied you are left feeling empty like "That's it?" and concerned that you'll be done and tired of this game really quick.TLDR: Player 2 experience sucks, game lacks content and is dry, does NOT actually have full controller support. I'd honestly just buy force awakens or complete saga over this game.Now that I've critiqued the game I will say this is by far the BEST looking Lego game to date as they switched to a new engine and the graphics are simply stunning. The art team did an outstanding job I will give them that so honestly that's about the sole thing that carries the open world...while it's boring gameplay wise, it is beautiful to take in.

author: Aperture Dude
review: The game is really well done. The developers spend a lot of time making a Galaxy Far, Far Away feel complete. Throughout the game the story is abridged since it is a Lego game and meant more so for kids, but can be enjoyed by adults as well. In regards to the Sequel Trilogy, they poke a bit more fun at it then the OT and PT but overall it is still enjoyable. Completing the game to 100% will take a bit of time, for me it was just under 70 hours, for others it could be 80 or more, but you will definitely get your money's worth. If you are even somewhat a Star Wars Fan and enjoy the Lego games, this game is for you.

author: Mech Muffin
review: Ok, first off, this game has massively positive reviews.  Classic case of nostalgia blinders.  Let me tell you first why I can talk about this game and second why I think it's subpar for Lego games.First, I've played almost every single Lego game released (even those old ones like Rock Raiders and Lego Racer), so I've been a fan of these games since I was a kid.  I've played all the Lego Star Wars games (except I hardly touched TFA).  Ok, so let's get into why I don't recommend this game.1. Level design: The levels are very, very short.  Like some can be completed in 5 minutes.  They probably average around 10 minutes, the longest maybe at 15.  Don't expect excellent level design like in previous titles.  No puzzles, hardly any areas to explore.  Only collectibles are studs and like 5 parts of a minikit.  This game decided to focus on semi-open world hubs with short missions interspersed.  I'd be fine with that if the open world had anything interesting to offer.  90% of the worlds are focused around collecting kyber bricks, and after a few hours, you realize all the puzzles to get the kyber bricks are recycled every planet.  There are a few side quests that really stand out, but there are few of them.  Overall, level design is very poor, and the short levels just aren't made up for by the bland open worlds.Even more disappointing to me was the removal of several key levels from the previous Complete Saga game.  There is no Battle over Coruscant.  There is no space battle over Endor.  These are skimmed over in quick cutscenes, like 10-20 seconds long.  Very disappointing considering how much potential this game had.2. Character selection: There are a ton of characters in this game, and the Skywalker Saga doesn't ignore some of the more obscure characters, which I appreciate.  Unfortunately, as in most Lego games, about 80% of the characters are identical in how they act and attack, the only difference being their appearance.  There are unique voicelines for key characters which I found very enjoyable, and the company leaned hard into memes, especially prequel memes, which added a lot of enjoyment for me.  Jetpack characters got a hard nerf.  You can only hover low over the ground for about 3 seconds before you run out of fuel.  Very disappointing considering how far you could fly as Jango and Boba in previous titles (I have heard Bo Katan's jetpack is much better, but I haven't tried it myself).  The Jedi characters have several different lightsaber combat animations now which is a positive note.  They all handle pretty differently and are unique and fun.  Blaster characters on the other hand are very bland and boring to play.  The over the shoulder style camera for blaster combat is great for fighting but less so for trying to clear out an area of breakable objects.  The blaster characters in general didn't have enough differences to make them interesting.  3. Fighters and space combat: this was a big step forward for Lego who up till now had kept fighters locked into a flat plane with really weird camera angles.  Now you fly starfighters with 3rd person perspective camera and can fly any direction.  Unfortunately, there's very little to do in space.  There are some encounters, but they become repetitive after a few hours.  But the starfighter levels are amazing, especially the Droid Control Ship over Naboo.  Wish we'd gotten more of these levels instead of having them zipped past in cutscenes.4.  The story: Closely tied to the levels, the story is enjoyable but far too rushed.  Episode I in particular skips over major story points.  It probably took me 30-50 minutes to complete the whole episode.  Each episode only has 5 levels as well...  Again, missed potential.  There's no reason to limit each episode to 5 levels.  I know the devs wanted players to spend more time in the open world, but then again, they should have given us more to do in the open world.  Anyway, the story is fun, has good humor, but is too short.Overall, this game is fun for a few hours but becomes stale soon after.  The graphics are beautiful, but good graphics do not make a good game.  In my opinion, the Lego Star Wars Complete Saga and Lego Clone Wars games are far superior in level design, story, and replayability.   The Skywalker Saga has little to no replayability, and considering the short levels, it's hard to excuse a $60 (more if you get DLC) price tag.  The official MechMuffin rating for the Skywalker Saga: 4/10  Missed potential, and save your money.  Go play Lego Clone Wars.

author: 女孩子超忙的
review: What s blaze! It’s my first LEGO game, I am so impressed with this franchise, the investment was totally worth the shot. In fact, it’s the first purchase in 2022 I’ve done that I truly felt worth every penny I’ve spent in a game.StoryJust like the movies and how they go, but with some hilarious twists from TT. Seriously, I can’t stop laughing while going through the stories. It’s family friendly, you can safely play it with kids using co-op:)ContentThe game offers rich vast content for you to discover. I divided them into a few small sections below.-Mode-Apart from story mode, the game also gives you the Free mode after completing an episode. It allows you to play any characters you’ve unlocked, run freely to all the locations you’ve been to from stories to collect anything you’ve left out. Hundreds of side missions, challenges, mini games are waiting for you to completed. So you can access these content normally without competing all 9 episodes at any time you wish.-Collectibles-There are thousands of collectibles for you to collect across the mega university of galaxy: characters, ships’ skins, skill points currency...Well, it’s a LEGO version of the classic assassin’s creed, I am not exaggerating, I repeat, literally thousands lol.-Artwork-Everything is transformed to the art models of LEGO toys, while maintaining the high quality of how neat they look, all models are amazingly in detail.-Voice-Everyone including most of the NPC on the maps is beautifully voiced, I am not sure whether all the characters are voiced by the original actors and actresses in the films, however, they don’t  sound much different to me at very least. Personally, great job to all voice actors/actresses!LengthThe game is said to be around 15 hours to go through all the story lines, if you speed run it. In reality, there are so many places to explore, so many fun collectibles to gather, so many side fun missions and challenges to completed, you probably won’t rush the game to end, so the gameplay time extends much much longer than 15 hours, easily over 50 hours I tell you, it’s a mega open-world game, in my opinion, the price it offers is worth the time you are going to sink.Performance&GraphicsGame runs smoothly with my 65 inches ROG-PG65UQ 4K display with 120 FPS at cap. No lag, no FPS drops, no stutter, nothing, apart from some bugs. Graphics look like this:   with max-out settings.And the game terrifically supports HDR, when it’s on, the visuals are even beyond what it looks here, with vibrant and vivid colors. The reason I couldn’t screenshot them is: HDR features lose when taking a screenshot, they just won’t record to the image, so the final outcome significantly loses color details which is nothing it looks like in the game. Couldn’t share them is pity, though there is no doubt how amazing they are while HDR’s on. If you also have a HDR monitor, you will be impressed, it is as good as Lucas’s films which is presenting in front of your eyes.BugThe only drop back is: the game does have variety kinds of bugs. Like cutscenes turn to black screen when sound still going on. The button promote on screen are wrong sometimes when using a controller. Game occasionally freeze when bugged out. It doesn’t remember your visuals settings, for example FPS is set beyond 60. Though nothing game-breaking.Update: the game contains massive amount of bugs, they do not prevent you from completing the whole story, but some game-breaking bugs do successfully stopping me from 100% completion. PURCHASE WITH CAUTION!SumIf you like LEGO’s cute family friendly art style, get the game! If you are a Star Wars fan, and don’t mind it’s a cute version, get the game! If you are not in either of the group, and interested in this game, I highly recommend you trying it out.It’s pity this game no longer being introduced globally. It’s better spending your time playing video games rather than fighting the war, no?

author: Clinker2000
review: I wanted to love this game so badly especially after being a huge fan of the originals but i just can't. - The levels are so short and feel so dumbed down and stripped of puzzles, building, combat, secrets, meaningful collectables and everything that made them great in the originals. They've got no where near as much to interact with and they feel repetitive and rushed and even feel like you're speed running them at certain points. They've had so much removed and they've lost their charm and even the cut scenes feel rushed and out of place sometimes. I even went back and played The Complete Saga after playing this game and the first level of Phantom Menace took me maybe 20 minutes to get through on there after doing all the puzzles and collecting studs, whereas that mission on The Skywalker Saga took no more than 5 minutes to complete even after looking around and collecting studs and there weren't even any puzzles on that mission. Somehow the missions feel like a second thought in this game and I think way too much time was put into the bland open world rather than the main missions. - I think one of the worst parts of the game are the open hub areas, there's just too many of them (a new one after most missions and even multiple per planet) and they're all just filled with the same boring and repetitive puzzles, endless collectable kyber bricks and pointless NPC dialogue. It ruins the flow and immersion of the story having to go to them after nearly every level. They're as wide as an ocean but about as deep as a puddle and I hate having to access the main missions through them, it makes them feel tacked on. - The hacking puzzles are so repetitive and terrible, especially the R2D2 ones which are the exact same puzzle every single time.  - Combat is mindless. It obviously wasn't the strongest point in the older games either but it's still extremely simple and the new combat mechanics feel pointless to use when most enemies die in a few hits anyway. With the gun fights, most of the time you'll just stand in the same spot shooting down a hallway over and over again until the enemies are dead. - The UI and menus are a cluttered mess. There's so many things on screen and you don't need 95% of it. Looks so much messier and intrusive compared to the simple and clean original games UI.- The quick time events have literally no impact on game play whether you win or lose or are too fast for them. For example the Darth Vader lightsaber duel on Bespin, even when you win the QTE, Luke loses and when I purposely lost the QTE, Luke still beat Vader? It's the same with the object pulling QTEs, you don't even have to wait for the circles to align to successfully complete it, you can click the corresponding button as soon as it appears for the same affect.- The environments and characters do look great though and the roster of playable characters is impressive. It's still goofy and filled with funny moments too.Nearly everything in this game is a downgrade from the originals though. Obviously some people are gonna love the new format but having played the original games and enjoying them so much more than this new one, it all just feels so disappointing and I don't understand how it's had so many positive reviews.

author: RedDuelist
review: Definitely the best Lego Star Wars, it kept all the nostalgia from the earlier Lego Star Wars games, but with more newer introduced characters like The Mandalorian. The humor and comedy is still there in every cut scene and it's a thrill to finish the game and relive the movies in a fresh way. Next to that the replayability is high, you can come back for the ole trusty True Jedi statuses by collecting enough studs to fill three bars, collecting all the Kyber bricks and of course all the mini kits. Next to the 40 hours that I played already, I still have a long way to go on the achievements (19/45 currently) and getting all the mini-kits, characters and ships!

author: darth.crevette
review: Well, where to begin. A 100 hours for a Lego video game is nice, too bad halfway through it strated feeling like a chore.On paper, the skywalker Saga has everything to be one of the best Star Wars games ever made:So yes, if nothing else, this game has a  of content. Too bad most of it feels like padding.The story itself is super short. There's 5 missions per movie, most of them are around 5 minutes long; if you're not interested in collectables (but why are you even playing a Lego game in that case?) you're only in for 10 hours or so.But then, these collectibles. There's just  too many of them, most of which are  too easy and repetitive. I'd rather collect all Korok seeds in Breath of the Wild again, than try to 100% this game a second time. It's just "quantity over quality" taken to a (bad) extreme.While there's a lot of characters, half of them are just useless, either because... they just are (like most of those in the "Extra" category, who don't have any weapon or ability), or because others from the same class are just plain better. It feels like the devs just chose some random names from a SW wiki to add them to the game.Space battles are super boring. there's no dogfight or anything interesting going on, most of the time you don't even have to move, just stay in place and turn around to follow the enemy markers, dodge when the game tells you to, repeat for the next battle. Capitzl ships aren't much better, but at least you need to fly around a bit to hit all the targets.I won't talk about difficulty (or lack thereof), but just know there an invincibility option or an auto-dodge in the accessibility menu. Because apparently the game playing itself while you watch is "accessibility"...Then there's the technical issues (severe FPS drops in some areas, random CTD 3 or 4 times in total) and glitches (some of which haven't been addressed since launch)...

author: SSgt. Bananas
review: Shameful game at the end of the day. This is a worse game than the original Star Wars Lego games in every way. While I am not as young as when they came out the game is laughably easy with puzzles that always complete themselves. The only good addition is the combat system which is poorly done. There are not enough enemies to use it on as common ones die too soon to even actually combo against and bosses almost always have immunity to regular attacks unless you are countering a move. There's also a lack of enemies outside of the space battles in the open world to fight, sometimes in a Lego game I just want to switch my brain off and fight people with a lightsaber, I shouldn't have to spend as long finding a spawn point to do so. Platforming has also been removed completely with simple button presses advancing you to the next part of the level. At the end of the day this is an overpriced game that plays off nostalgia and I wish that I hadn't fallen for the trap myself upon release. I wish the game at least had more difficulty to it. I've yet to die once in the game, and while you can argue it's a kids game I feel that when paying full price for such a game in today's industry difficulty options should be present. I think that the very best thing this game could be described as is a let down, and for the worse side I consider it a vast downgrade from games that came out in 2005 with a higher asking price. There is attempt at mimicry of advancement when in reality we receive a pseudo-complex system for combat that boils down to "don't use the same attack more than 3 times consecutively", lobotomised platforming and self-playing puzzles.

author: Snowywarriors
review: Regrettably, I cannot recommend this game, despite my desire to do so. While the character options are fantastic, and the story is enjoyable, the game's current state falls short of expectations even at its lowered price point of $50. As a three-time buyer of this game on various platforms, I have experienced the best and worst of what it has to offer.On the positive side, the game's character options are impressive, and the story, while not without flaws, remains engaging. However, the game is grindy, which I found tiresome after spending many additional hours pursuing achievements and unlocking all the characters and minikits. The replay value of the story is also limited, with only key missions available to replay, leaving the player feeling unsatisfied with the overall experience.The co-op experience, a hallmark of previous Lego Star Wars games, was frustratingly marred by frequent game-breaking bugs, which caused the game to crash or freeze. While the game is still enjoyable in single-player mode, it lacks the charm that made its predecessors great.Ultimately, I wanted to like this game, but the various issues it presents make it difficult to recommend. However, I believe that there is still potential here, and I hope that the developers take note of the community's feedback and work to improve the game's shortcomings. If you're a fan of grindy games or looking for a mindless single-player experience, this game may still be worth considering, but be aware of its limitations in co-op mode and replay value.TLDR: I wanted so much to like this game, as I've played many Lego games as a kid and am a huge fan of them. If there was a neutral vote, this game would be it. But if I was considering downvoting it, I felt I had to represent that on Steam. There is so much love and potential here, so give it a shot if you want, but please be warned of the games pitfalls.

author: MIBEZIOR
review: This game is in such a tough spot for me. As someone who grew up playing the Lego games, not just Star Wars ones. Technically speaking, this game is magnificent with the amount of things you can do, as well as the visuals/audio. They are all leaps ahead of their predecessors, especially compared to the original Lego Star Wars the Complete Saga game.Gameplay wise, however, these games take steps backwards. The easiest way I can describe this game is that it is akin to Assassin's Creed games, where you have A LOT of things to do, but nothing of substance. While old Lego games involved a huge number of quests to acquire bricks and whatnot, the activities and challenges you did were a lot more varied and creative. In this game, there isn't a lot of variety. Of the things that are here, the creativity is lacking. It led to me getting bored and I couldn't be bothered to slog through half of the quests on half of the planets because I couldn't stand grinding the same repeated quests any more.The other main irritant is the way that characters are handled. I won't get into the voice lines vs mumbles debate, although I firmly believe the mumbles and old style of talking had a lot more charm to it. Characters, as opposed to having a huge roster of distinct and unique characters, are now broken up into certain classes of character (you have Jedi, Scavenger, Bounty Hunter, etc.). These classes result in characters not feeling unique anymore, since each class MUST have a distinct class ability, they are required to be able to do things that don't make sense for that character. Because characters don't feel as unique, it makes the process of acquiring new ones a lot less satisfying than the past. The way that DLC is being handled is also a headache for me personally. I know that Disney is coming out with more Star Wars products/shows as time goes on, so TT obviously couldn't fit everything into the game without an easy compromise. But the way that character packs are being doled out is seriously irritating. Because they are ONLY characters, they run into the previous issue that I wrote about characters themselves. They boil down to skins of a certain class. Which is sort of acceptable if the pack has characters that all fit into different classes, but is absolutely absurd when packs have nothing but one or two classes in them (such as the trooper pack). It means that packs will have different value associated, and like I said before, they are only skins for classes. They don't include any other content of any kind. No levels, ships, areas, etc. What's worse is that these packs don't get included for those who buy the Deluxe Edition, which, for an extra $10 USD, nets you a couple included character packs.It is disappointing because again, this game should and could be one of the best Lego games of all time. If this game is on sale, then I'd say it might be worth buying. Or if you're unable to play previous Lego games or really just want to play the latest and greatest and don't have an interest in any previous games. But otherwise, I do not recommend buying this game in its current state. I didn't even mention the technical issues that this game runs into, as well as a myriad of UI or quality of life issues that also hinder the user experience.

author: AFatalPapercut
review: If you've played a LEGO game in the past you more or less know what you're in for already, the general game flow and such.  But for some reason this game feels like it refreshes the formula a bit.  If it isn't broke, don't fix it...but you might be able to shine it up a bit.  There seems to be quite a bit of content to last a long while, each level or stage or whatever has been a pretty decent length. The graphics are pretty great for a LEGO game, and the jokes are actually decent (when the wall blew up and the Stormtroopers were in the hot tub, "this is not the pod you're looking for," I cracked up a bit) The combat seems to be a mix of say...Batman melee and GOW shooting.  All in all I think you'll be pleased with this if you enjoy LEGO games already, like Star Wars, or even if this is your first jump into the game series it's never been in a better spot IMHO.**I don't think there's character customization like in the past for whatever reason, so if that's your thing, you might be pretty disappointed it's not present**

This is a key moment in the movie how can you get it so wrong ?????????????????This is one of many ♥♥♥♥ ups through the entire game, this one just caught my eye and made me ragequit.THIS DOESNT EVEN MAKE SENSE BECAUSE MAUL GETS HIS LEGS BACK IN THE OFFICIAL CLONE WARS SERIES, HE CANT BE DEAD AND THEN ALIVE AGAIN.It angers me that no one in the development team and or the quality control even watched star wars, everyone that ever worked on this does not know the REAL movies and SERIES by LUCASARTS. WHAT A MONEYGRAB.

author: Legitwaffles
review: As a profound Star Wars fan, its my responsibility to expose this game for what it is. I’ve completed this game 100% with almost 90 hours into it. The Good: The graphics are immensely beautiful and comparable to the EA Battlefront titles. Cutscenes are sometimes funny and are nostalgic of the old films and from “Lego Star Wars the complete saga”. The Bad: There are a lot of flaws in this game. I recommend watching Doktor Skippers Critique video on the matter. However, to summarize how bad this game is, this is a short list.- Has zero replay ability - The Levels are all “start at point A and go to B” or boss fight- Some episodes have long, uninteresting levels that can put most people to sleep - Boss fights are unchallenging (like press a button and you win unchallenging)- Large cast of characters that are identical to each other (lacking uniqueness with the exemption of their class roles) - a lot of dead space between missions (ex. A lot of walking and doing nothing) - Level collectibles are uncreative and lack flair old lego games had when pursuing mini kits - Level challenges suck (You’ll just look up a video on how to do some of them, as they are either tedious or repetitive). - Over 1000 collectibles in a vast over world… but the majority share the exact same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ objective/instruction or ask the same premise. Seriously… why are there around 45 smuggle missions??- And lastly, a mountain full of bugs, glitches, and crashes.TLDR: Buy the complete saga instead… or Lego Star Wars 3 if it interests you. This game falsely advertises a bigger game. I can only recommend it if you are a diehard star wars fan and want to go insane doing the exact same task to obtain collectibles. Rate it 3/10

author: rArnold
review: So, after playing through all the episodes and getting more than 50% of the galaxy completion I can’t say I’m happy with the final product. The levels in the game are painfully short, like some can be beaten in under 5 minutes and they aren't very imaginative either. This isn't just compared with other Lego Star Wars games but almost every Lego TT game which always found ways of adding to a scene. There are also only 5 levels per film which wouldn't be bad if they were longer and didn't sometimes consist of a singular area, (yes really). I also went to replay a vehicle mission in free play (a space one), and it would not let me pick a different ship.Also, the story is quick and abrupt and has some weird changes, but I think this was partially Disney's standards and practises not letting some characters be killed and instead comically knocked out while Darth Maul gets hacked to pieces ( I know he lives in the clone wars but that’s not in the game)Then there's also the unnecessary additions of both shooter cover and melee combo trees. Enemies are so weak and easy to kill that it's more efficient to just shoot them. The combo trees feel like nothing more than an arbitrary attempt to make combat more interesting, but the game is so easy it doesn't matter. There's nothing wrong with the game being easy, it is after all, for really young kids but it renders these additions pointless, most children will also be able to figure out cover is useless. The bosses are really boring too, there's rarely if ever any puzzle element and just mash attack while occasionally dodging The open world segments are in fairness really good, one major positive about the skywalker saga is that it has one of the best Star Wars worlds to explore.  Even the sequels' worlds are fleshed out and are given new life.  It makes you want to explore them.  The open worlds consist of puzzles and quests to do and are lot are classic Lego puzzles with the twist that you can solve in a few more ways. Can't be bothered to stack all the boxes slowly? Stack destructible items and use them instead, can't use a scavenger with a glider yet? Fling another character with a force push and switch to them to get the kyber brick.  The quests are very simple, don't expect brilliant quest design there just another means to an end. While the open world segments may be good, don't expect the rewards to be. There are over 1000 kyber bricks in the game. 6 per level and others are rewards. After a while they are useless. Sure, you could upgrade your skills but after a few select ones there is no point, in fact it can be a detriment if you're trying to grind for studs via a combo meter. There is no real point in going for 100% unless you get the 100% reward (it's a pointless stud fountain, don’t bother) or the characters.The characters suck a bit too. There's classes for characters which isn't a bad thing but because of this there isn't much uniqueness to them. They use the same abilities. Even Jedi and Sith are disappointing, the only difference being a unique force grab and whatever upgrade paths they have. Abilities like force lighting are restricted to stupid combo trees, you can't just pull it out which might have actually added some more puzzle variety. I’m not expecting every character to be unique but the game is sorely lacking variety.The game is a chore to play IMO, like all Lego games can get tedious after a long session but every time I came back to play it wasn’t fun.It feels rushed; it was rushed despite delays. TT employees suffered major crunch because of bad and stupid management as feature creep set in. I would honestly love to see the state of this during its intended release. This game could have benefited from being more a sandbox like lego is supposed to be instead of a weird mashup of genres.While Custom characters are not everything, we know it was supposed to be in the game and it could have benefited from a ship builder too. I mean anything new and interesting do with those kyber bricks would have been great.

author: TheOneSandwich
review: SPOILER WARNING: If you haven’t seen any of the Star Wars movies, sorry. The original trilogy only came out 30 years ago, so I understand if you missed it.    On November 6, 2007, history was made — or, at least, my childhood was made, as  was released (jeez, fourteen and a half years ago). You’d be hard-pressed to find a child at the time that didn’t at least play a little bit of the game. So when  was announced, I couldn’t wait to get my hands on it. And while my wallet whimpered a little at the $50 dollar price tag, I was still excited to give the game a whirl. As such, here’s my honest review.    This review comes from playing through about 50% of the story. The story is, predictably, a comedic retelling of the entire Star Wars main line of movies. It succeeds in its purpose, hitting all the comedic notes in a way that felt less outside my age range (looking at you, ) and more akin to the older style of visual comedy, with some casual one-liners to emphasize the point of it being a joke.     This is the part where I fully admit it. I don’t like the voice lines. All the characters feel like bad impressions of the actual cast. This was mitigated in 2007 by having the characters never voice any lines. That worked, and meant they had to get creative with how they told the big moments. With dialogue, not only are they less creative, it feels like they try to hit every single major quote in the scenes (there is an option to turn off the dialogue in favor of the usual mumbling they do, but the scenes are definitely built for dialogue and the mumbling only serves to take away from the delivery of the lines in favor of clinging stubbornly to nostalgia).     Maybe that’s nitpicking. After all, I am no longer in the target demographic (I’d imagine a 20-year-old isn’t exactly the model target audience for LEGO). However, I’ve mentioned the word “nostalgia” perhaps a little too much now, and that’s for good reason. I mentioned the mumble option earlier, but there are a multitude of quick nostalgia trips the game decides to take, which means they knew that people like me would be getting the game. As such, I reserve the right to criticize the game.    Another criticism I have — the menu is super cluttered. I open the pause menu to see where I have to go, and I have 5 different things screaming at me with yellow dots, signaling me that there’s something new to look at. It’s distracting, I was just trying to see the layout of Tatooine. Also, there’s an upgrade tree. That’s kinda weird. It’s not offensively bad, it’s just… there. And I don’t know how to feel about it.    I, very luckily indeed, haven’t really encountered too many glitches, at least not game-breaking ones. Except one. For whatever reason, if I hit Alt+Tab to say, check an email I got, for whatever reason, the game will completely refuse to open. It’ll bring up a black screen before booting me out again. I tried setting it to borderless windowed mode, but then it leaves the taskbar visible and cuts off the bottom of the screen. I gave up on playing the game once because of this. It happened multiple times, each time after I decided to check something using Alt+Tab.      I realize that the paragraphs above paint a perhaps negative picture of the game. This isn’t entirely my intention. I really like the game, I find that it keeps the charm that makes (almost) all LEGO games great. It’s oozing with enthusiasm to tell you Star Wars’s story the way only it can. And I honestly fully bought into that. At the end of the day, I couldn’t say this is a masterpiece of a game. Nor do I expect it to be a relic of people’s childhoods like was. But it’s a good game, it’s fun to play, and it tells the story in a new and interesting way. And honestly, what more is there to ask from a LEGO game?Was it worth the $50, though? Jury’s still out on that one. Maybe wait for it to go on sale before you buy it.

author: Beer Baron
review: I wish I could give this game a “mixed” review, but the bugs ultimately pushed me to rate it negative.  There’s a lot of good nostalgia playing this game.  I remember playing these old lego games on my game cube and loving them.  This version however is a bit of a mixed bag.The good:• I actually liked the “open world” approach to this series as opposed to previous versions very linear style.• Lots of little quests, space battles and neat little puzzles to solve.• Lots of characters and ships to choose from in free play mode.• The story line is humorous (not haha funny, more dad joke funny).The bad:• 6 months later and there are still game breaking bugs.  My current game is stuck at 99.98% complete because one of the side quests is bugged and there is no way to reset it.  When I submitted the error I got a boiler plate response of “maybe we will fix it eventually”.  Pretty unacceptable for there to still be game breaking bugs 6 months after release.• Lots and lots of running around to different planets for quests.  You will spend the majority of your game-play running from one side of a map to another.Conclusion:I can’t recommend it until they fix some of these game breaking bugs.  If you’re a completionist and liked getting “100%” on previous versions, I would be wary about purchasing this version.  If you just want to play it for the corny story, you should be fine.

author: GAMMARAZOR
review: First-off, this is, by far, the best LEGO game, and it's an excellent tribute to The Complete Saga. The game has some bugs (noteably 'The Missing Pieces' and 'The High Ground' softlocks), but it's absolutely incredible despite those. The combat feels fluid, the ship flying feels better than Battlefront (the good one, not the new one), and it really shows that new games can be better than the originals. Long story short, if you have $50 or $60 to spend and you like Star Wars, get this game. It's worth every penny.

author: Cydonia or Bust
review: This is the most visually stunning LEGO game ever released. The vistas are breath-taking, sweeping, and gorgeous. The revamped combat system adds a level of franticness to fights. By all the parts separately and piecemeal, this should be a thing I really like. The inspirations and level design are clearly drawn from titles like the LEGO Ninjago Movie Video Game, and the more recent superhero games like Marvel 2 and DC Supervillains, especially the notion of hopping through a hub world and telling a story there as much as the story is told through levels.Unfortunately, due to things like "running faster" being upgrades, this slows down the pace of the story pretty significantly, with excellent voice acting in the hub worlds during the story missions (perhaps the best in any voice acted lego game, and yes, these are story missions, this is an open-world game now, I'm very frustrated by this but that's personal preference and thus not important to this review) being secondary to my frustration at having to play walking simulator. The vehicles in the hub world, like the Coruscant walker, are not meaningfully quicker than taking 2 levels of sprint, which is a horrible gamer-y thing to say about a LEGO game. There are other systems and mechanics to complain about, like the promising combat revamp (it's now a wasd-mouse title for non-controller players, wow!) and how it tends to make fights feel even less engaging. If you were bored by the superheroes games and how they approached fighting mechanically (visually fantastic and fun, really established character styles), it basically takes the very cool combo system from ninjago, adds the sponginess of the superhero games and adds some shooting to it, all to make a perfect storm of mechanical genius and gameplay mediocrity. I genuinely wish I had nicer things to say, because I've been excited for and evangelizing this game for months. I'll probably 100% it out of spite, and in the hopes that I adjust to all these details that I've been complaining about. If that's the case, and I end up liking this mechanically, I'll flip the thumb to positive then, and consider rewriting this wacky essay.

author: Kopec
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2020 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. We spent 7 hours on the game that night and we had killed the first 3 bosses. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: Plushman1
review: After spending at least almost 130 hours trying to 100% the game and quite possibly tearing out my own hairs and eating them...I think this game is completely underwhelming. Here's why.Controls- It controls pretty good, although bit janky on whenever you swing pole to pole or on the little things (I forgo what they are called)Combat- It feels like babies first DMC, with all of the combos and sh*t like that. I find the combat fun and it does feel a little bit satisfying to pull off the combos.Quest Design- There's all kinds of quests in the game. Escort, Smuggling stuff to other planets, ect, ect. I find it completely garbage, since it repeats over and over again with nothing of value...and some of the sidequests are completely BS (see "The Final Gonk").Map/Level Design- The game follows a 5 level format, with 3 level challenges and 5 minikits to collect and some open world's stuff to do. The pacing of the levels are completely weird as they take 5-10 minutes (or longer if you're just messing around and trying to get the minikits), and some of the levels are on rails sections, meaning that there is no point of playing Freeplay. In fact, most of the levels don't really require freeplay to complete it, you can just be a Hero and grind for Villain costumes to put on, and you've already 100% the level. The open world sections are completely there just to pad out the story, so the episodes lasts only an hour and 30 minutes. One final thing, the fights between the Jedis and Siths are completely the same with no different movesets of how the siths fight.Graphics- I really like them! I think the models are completely superb, the environments look completely good too and I really like the details to some of the models. QTE's (Quick Time Events)- The game does have them, and there is literally no consequences for not pressing the button, because sometimes the game automatically does that for you, which I feel is completely lame. Like I get it, the game's for children, but at least have consequences of not pressing the required button. And spoilers btw!That's why the whole fight between Luke and Kylo Ren is really lame, because it's just a QTE mash. It makes sense why, but it just feels lame as hell.Voice Acting- I think it's fine for the most part, but does feel a bit off for the characters. Stability- The game runs fine, and is generally smooth. Unless you're in certain areas, that's when the game starts to dip to either 10 or 20 FPS...also expect random crashes. Oh, before I forget, USE BORDERLESS FOR YOUR GAME AND DONT ALT TAB IN FULLSCREEN Conclusion- That's pretty much it, also I couldn't 100% the game because some a**hole at WB thought it'd be a great idea to delay a patch to add in DLC characters, thank you WB. Love ya, as always LOL as for my rating for the game:5.5/10

author: lanuarii
review: Did you ever hear the tragedy of Darth Plagueis The Wise? I thought not. It’s not a story the Jedi would tell you. It’s a Sith legend. Darth Plagueis was a Dark Lord of the Sith, so powerful and so wise he could use the Force to influence the midichlorians to create life… He had such a knowledge of the dark side that he could even keep the ones he cared about from dying. The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural. He became so powerful… the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.

author: hyperweasle
review: TLDR: Game is fun, but not worth full price. Wait for a discount.This is the type of game that makes me I wish Steam had a in between rating. So um, I will say I recommend it, but not at full price. The problem is that it's downgrade in alot of ways to the complete saga, for instance the hub world NPCs only have like two actions, walk and run away if attacked. At first I was ok with it since they were all defenseless citizens. That was until I realized almost every NPC in the hub areas are like that including Clone Troopers. Yes, the Republic's finest on Coruscant will run away at the first sight of danger. There are few exceptions where I came across some Storm Troopers in Cloud City, but that is rare sight. Not only that, but if you switch to a Dark Side character, the hub NPCs, other than a select few, will not react to you any differently, nor can you use dark side abilities on them. Sadly this game also suffers from game breaking bugs as well, which may have been fixed in patches, but I had problems with indefinite black screens during transitions causing me to restart the game again. Along with performance issues that cause the game to dip to down to 40 fps on a RTX 2060 and Ryzen 7 5800x. The graphics are improved, but not by that much that it should be causing performance in selects areas to go below 60 fps, even lower the settings does very little to help with it.The best change is the player combat and boss battles which I do feel are improved over the complete saga. Having the ability to use combos to earn studs, to aim a blaster and light saber throw, and use the force to manipulable objects in any direction you want is really good.Lastly the custom characters are removed which wouldn't have been a huge deal if the game was well refined, but it's not. The game itself lack so much polish that I really have a hard time forgiving removing such a key feature that was present in all other Lego games go back all the way to Lego Star Wars II while lacking the polish of those game. Keep in mind this isn't even the first open world Lego game, the DC and Marvel Lego games are also open world and have so much more polish and more interesting NPCs in the hub areas, which makes me wonder where all the development went into on this game, I can't imagine the player characters took so much effort to improve that all other aspects of the game suffered.

author: Southey
review: After finally finishing the story of the Lego Star Wars The Skywalker saga’s story,This is possibly the most disappointing Lego game I have ever played!The stories are painfully short for each episode throughout the saga, space battles last ten to five minutes long. It took me give or take 2 hours to finish each episode from the saga. Someone might have done it quicker. So after losing the refund time, I thought I might as well carry on.The transitions between the episodes' stories got tiresome, walking from point A to B , click start mission. Which could have been solved using cut-scenes. Now the cut-scenes are badly placed and help remove fun. Could you have a space battle ? Yes we could've , did we get one ? No.  Episode 3 ‘s intro is a good example of this.  Sure you have 9 episodes to do and it would take longer, but it would be nice if missions weren’t watered down with cut-scenes. The good thing was the new mechanics of using a lightsaber differently, the P.O.V of aiming down sight, and characters having some unique skills. Though that isn't enough to make a game good.The games main focus was mostly making an open world filled with 1,166  ‘Kyber bricks’. To go and collect to upgrade your character's skill tree. Rather than the film's episode story.  Which i might end up doing if i'm  bored. If you want a good Lego Star Wars game I'd recommend the complete saga version.

author: ItaAndy
review: Did someone say Elden Ring? More like Lego The Skywalker Saga. Call me crazy, but this game, is THE BEST game so far in 2022. I'm a huge fan of Lego games, and this right here is an instant classic. Is it the best Lego game? Ouch, that made my head hurt, there are so so so (let's say all of them) all Lego games are fantastic. I will mention, the replay value in this game is outstanding. I've yet beaten the game, but the game is massive in content. So many characters to unlocked, so many blue bricks to find (over 1000!) so many ships, and so so much more, oh and many many side quest.  I can easily say, is the longest or one of the longest Lego games. The combat system is fresh new and it's so satisfying. The graphics are top notch, the humour always makes me giggle/smile.  If  you're looking to get your money's worth, look no further. Lego has you covered. I play this game with my wife, and we laugh and have a blast. We're in our 30's, and Lego games always bring out our inner child.

author: G3n0t
review: One of the best LEGO games ever made, with amazing new features, great graphics for a LEGO game, amazing combat, is a dream game for a LEGO and Star Wars fan. It's a shame there isn't a photo mode, as it would be amazing to take pictures in this game.Unfortunately I found a negative point, at least for me, and for those who are going to use keyboard+mouse it will be a little difficult to get used to the controls. The game has very little options for customizing the hotkeys, there are certain actions I would like to do with other hotkeys, but the game prevents me from using repeated hotkeys of my choice. The game has hotkeys that allow for various actions but I would like to choose what those actions would be instead of being predefined, since a keyboard contains several keys I think it wouldn't be a problem to have more choices and freedom in customizing the hotkeys.The game's sensitivity is also too high, even using the mouse's lowest DPIs, I still don't feel comfortable with the speed of camera movement.This are minimal criticisms that may not affect many people, but if they are improved it would be great.

author: jamestheredguy5
review: I'm just gonna be brief here.Aside from the EXTREMELY botched launch on PC here in the UK where the game came out the day AFTER it was supposed to release.I love this game for it's fanservice, humour, top quality voice acting and fun combat.But it's also one of the most boring video games I think I've ever played in my life.Now, yeah, I think the hype for this game was super justified, but I also think that this game REALLY didn't live up to the hype either.I do like the shorter levels, since I really do hate when LEGO game levels drag on, *cough* Ace Chemicals in LEGO Batman 2, I'm looking at you. *cough*But sometimes, some levels can be SUPER short, and I don't know why.I'm mixed on this game, because I adore how much pure love for Star Wars history, lore, characters and internet memes that the developers have crammed into this game, but it's also not enough to save a really boring experience that feels like a neutered version of all 9 movies.Also, I'm still furious that the Character Creator got removed, like... why?5/10It's a fun time for fans as well as children and their parents, but it's UNGODLY boring once you beat the story and get into Free Play, which normally is supposed to be the complete opposite in LEGO games.Also, for the DLC very briefly.Mando Season 1 pack is good for just getting Mando, every other character sucks.Mando Season 2 pack is amazing just for the novelty of getting Ahsoka Tano.Rouge One pack is great because it gives you a boat load of good characters for the price, also, you get Krennic, so 10/10 right there.Solo pack is good because the version of Han in that pack makes up for Indiana Jones not being in the game.Trooper pack exists.The Bad Batch pack sucks so hard it's not even funny, only buy this if you want to play as Hunter, since he's the only "unique" character in the pack.and Classic Characters is the best DLC pack in the game because you get to play as the original 1999 versions of the LEGO Star Wars minifigures, I love it.DLC is a strong 6/10

author: Schmillet
review: I wish I could give this game a mixed review.As someone that has played Lego Star Wars The Complete Saga, Lego Star Wars The Clone Wars, and even Lego Star Wars The Force Awakens, I have a hard time recommending this game. The new visuals and combat are a breath of fresh air and look and feel great, but the content is so lackluster that the visuals and combat are overshadowed completely. There are only five levels per movie, the longest one being maybe 15 minutes or so. Each level is the same sequence of watch a cutscene, fight some enemies, go here, fight some more, watch end cutscene. There are no fun puzzles like in other Lego games.The open world is where the bulk of the content is, if I can even call it that. Most of the missions require you to talk to a character, go fetch something, and come back. My only positive of the open world is the sheer size of it. Almost every important planet is available to explore.I have had fun playing it, but only in short bursts. It just doesn't have the same magic as any of the older Lego games.

author: | нsт | Victorino Mora
review: This was and is one of my most anticipated games of the year and it highly deserves praise for bringing the Lego series to a new frontier but I'm also going to critique it for a lot of the things I scratched my head wondering, "Why is this an issue?" or "Why wasn't this implemented when I've seen it before in previous titles?"Combat: This one immediately blew me out the water with how fantastic and expanded the game can feel. Each character ranges from Jedi, Bounty Hunter, Villain, Sith, Hero, Dark Side, Astromech Droid, Protocol Droid and on top of having these different classes each class has an ability tree that you can level up and grinding towards these Kryber Bricks actually feels rewarding because you'll be needing them.  Some characters have combos that feel a lot like Dmc or Darksiders. There's so many different animations and moves to perform, one of my favorite being the Bounty Hunter that will jump up in the air and spin attack down. Open World: If anyone has ever played SWTOR this game gives off those vibes and it's fantastic to be able to explore the world at your own pace as the game presents it. As soon as I and my friend landed on the first planet we spent maybe the first 20-30 minutes just free roaming and gathering bricks and trying to do all these side quests before heading to the next mission. The galaxy map and the planets feel populated and breathing. There's tons of hidden things to find and backtracking to do at later times. (This which is very familiar to Lego games in general but still a blast to do) Characters: I can't confirm this because truthfully I haven't beaten the game, but from what I've read there are about 380 characters in the game. Now with that being said there are also a huge amount of vehicles to use and collect. (I'm just going to add that I am a veteran to Lego games and a huge fan of them. Just because there are 380+ characters and vehicles does not mean that 380 are going to act differently from one another, be aware that a lot of these characters will just feel reskinned from the last one and there will probably be about 20-30 dynamic characters.)  Alright well, I'm going to critique the game, and I am also going to nit pick here and there what I don't like and I'll be sure to label that.Story: This is Star Wars. There really isn't a "wrong" way of doing it but the game feels extremely lackluster and far too fast paced for the amount of delays and time we had to wait. Each chapter has 5 main missions, and each of those missions will last about 4-7 minutes long. I told my friend to finish the first movie and I'd catch up with her, and by tomorrow we could play the 2nd. Well I got on, and within 30 minutes I finished the first movie. There are so many scenes that feel left out, rushed, and simply altered to keep the comedy rolling every 4 seconds. I know Lego's have always had their way of being funny but a lot of this feels forced. For the amount of delays we had to wait it makes me question what was their focus? I'm going to assume the open world because that's massive. My gripe with this is just how much more impact other lego games have had with little to say in terms of dialogue.Voice(Nitpick): I personally don't like the voice acting for a lot of characters and a huge amount of them feel butchered. Playing LegoLOTR that used the movie audio felt bootleg and lazy, but it was a nice form of keeping the cast sounding original and sticking as close to the script as possible. Here a lot of characters have voices completely changed, altered, and a lot of it just doesn't roll with me. This is a new generation and I'm happy people will get to enjoy newer voices but a lot of the emotion was cut and left out from what the movies had already established.Multiplayer. OKAY HOW CAN YOU GUYS NOT ADD THIS? HOW!?!? LEGO WORLDS HAS MULTIPLAYER, YOU GUYS HAVE A LEGO MMO THAT SUPPORTS MULTIPLAYER, HOW DOES THIS GAME NOT HAVE A FUNCTIONING MULTIPLAYER DROP IN DROP OUT FEATURE? IT'S 2022 GET WITH THE PROGRAM! YOU DELAYED THE GAME 3 TIMES AND NO ONE THOUGHT "hey we should probably add online multiplayer" Character Creation(Nitpick): It's gone. That's all I have to say, it's gone. :( Can't kill kids(Nitpick): Why come?Minor bugs N glitches: Yea I've run into a few of these, non of them game breaking for me (my friend did have to restart her game twice I think?) But for me I've only had visual effects, some enemies that don't die, and weird clippings into walls. Overall fun game, going to continue to play and enjoy it, that's all I really have to say.

author: Raf`
review: From the LEGO series I expected much more, I bought it due to all the hype around the game. In previous games the game added more content around the movie however in the Skywalker Saga it's the opposite it tries to include a narrative but fails so hard due to levels squeezed to minimum. The older series offered much better way of storytelling - even though the characters never spoke a word the game conveyed storytelling via the body language of the characters which looked also very comical, however now they in addition to body gestures they also speak, which completely changes the atmosphere and now everything seems overly goofy.Levels have very poor content, the first level travels the same path and back, defeating 3-4 group of enemies on the way. Mini games which are just not even fun and serve 0 gameplay purpose other than that they are just there. In previous games they diversified the gameplay after a long tough fight or a platformer puzzles and elements which in the first 4 levels were not only simply not there but were strictly 1 dimensional.And a lot of complicated useless levels, UI elements and gameplay mechanics.The first game ever that I wanted to refund

author: Anti-Material Girl
review: This is officially my new favorite lego game. Yes, it's better than lego city undercover, and that's a really high ♥♥♥♥♥♥ bar for me. I'd even say it's better than the complete saga! I absolutely recommend that everyone who can, give this game a chance because it's well worth playing. The amount of effort and attention to detail put into this game is astounding. Fantastic job guys, this absolutely lives up to the expectations of fans of legos and star wars alike.Also, PLEASE don't turn on mumble mode, the voice acting is really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ good.

author: Emerald
review: Is this even a LEGO game?This game is OK, but it simply does not belong with older LEGO games. If it had any other style, realistic, cartoonish, whatever, it'd still be the same and maybe even better game. I played most of the LEGO games (some as a kid, some for the first time only recently). There are better and worse LEGO games. With each of them you can find something done well and something that could be better.Open World problems:-  Always feels empty. Sure, there are some NPCs and stuff to break, but the NPCs don't really amount to anything and stuff to break is scattered so loosely. Older games (at least most of them) had playable characters walking around the world making it feel more alive. Often fighting their enemies.-  There is no place that would feel like home. Re-playable levels:- Levels which was the main thing of every LEGO game just aren't a thing here. Sure, they are present in the game, but the story/the level is nothing. Tiny area with almost nothing to do. Only few of the levels have something to do in them.-  A lot of key story elements are missing within the game. They don't have any level or they're skipped and never mentioned.Boss battles:-  Not inventive. You have to smash buttons. That's it. Where are the battles when you had to use the stuff around you? Now you have to fight till enemy's healthbar gets down.-  Fixed camera. Fixed camera is great thing as long as it is optional or there is nothing to do or to explore. And even then, a lot of players don't like fixed camera.Health bar:-  Is it easier to know how much HP your enemies have? Yup.  But it's not cool while fighting boss. Where used to be scary amount of hearts now is just ordinary health bar. New "leveling" system:-  Interesting concept, terrible execution. Was there a need for it? No.  This system would be great for any other game. If this wasn't LEGO game trying to be typical LEGO game.Target audience:-  Is this game for toddlers? Or for more mature playerbase?  The game seems to not be sure either.  You can expect me to do elaborate stuff (which is fun on its own) or let the game be easy and fun.  You can't expect somebody to play this game with equal seriousness as while playing any other non-LEGO Star Wars game while he's being fed with 1 hundred millions of suggestions and hints as if the person who playes it was infant. Pick one, or let me disable all the hints.Storytelling/Humor/Mumbling:-  The main reason why all the old LEGO games were such a good games and made us laugh was in the was its story was told = without words.  Now it's just bland retelling of story with something that is not funny.-  Who are the jokes for?  Infants? Typical US citizen?  Most jokes aren't funny because they're so bland and obvious. The story is told with voice actor so people responsible for jokes no longer have to come with something creative. Characters:-  There is so many playable character that it's hard to pick which to play. And not because there is so many to chose from, but because the system (UI) sucks. It is cool to have them split into smaller groups, but changing the character is nightmare. Especialy in free play, it's not very good.-  You can play as Yaddle or even rodian dancer. Which is cool, but it's way less cool when you realize how many iconic characters is missing in the game - Seasee Tin, Agen Kolar or Stass Allie.-  Some characters got updated texture in comparison to their irl LEGO figures, while others didn't. Or as one Kenobi has incorrect pattern on back. No character creator:-  LEGO game with no option to create your own character? That's just wrong.3rd Person camera:-  Why? What for? I get why, but was it needed? No, would it be better if the camera was  above as always.

author: Natezy
review: So far im really enjoying this game.Pros:Game looks beautifulGreat cutscenes HumorousGreat Voice Acting Level of detail is crazyCons: I feel that some scenes that could easily have been small missions / levels are cutscenes which kinda suck.There are ALOT of collectibles to get could get very repetitive once you finish the episodesOther than that this game is great and I can see many hours being put into this gameNote: I havent finished the episodes yet this is just from the first few hours of playing and how I feel about this game so far...So far Id rate it 7/10 - I havent been this excited playing a game in a long time and Im not disappointed, I hope many kids find this game being a part of their childhoods like I did with Lego Star Wars The Complete SagaEdit: They took out fights that should have been fights but instead its just a quick cutscene- 6/10 :)

author: Lee Mcufflin
review: The actual "Campaign" Is over so fast and the game is so easy, the only time I've died in combat or during the duels is falling off ledges, hell i haven't even played the new films because i just don't want to so i can't comment on that but i bet they're more fleshed out than the Prequels and Original Series, I can't recommend this to someone looking for Story because there is non, half of the battles are done with Cutscenes, take The Battle of Coruscant,  Mace's confrontation with Palpatine and the Attack on the Second Death Star for example, all the conflicts i was looking forward to with the game but they aren't present in a playable state. you just watch it unfold in crackhead speed.The rest of the game is just all about collecting the blue bricks and characters through side quests that are quite menial in the grand scale of it all, eh, guess your kid will enjoy it.

author: SomeRandomFadgit
review: I so wish I could recommend this game, it was the most fun I've had playing a lego game, had a minor bug at the start of episode 2 that made a level unplayable, nothing a quick restart couldn't fix.However that wouldn't be the last problem, I played the game as normal, all through episodes 2-4, after the first level of episode 5, I found myself with a large amount of studs at my disposal, so I decided to put the main story on hold for a while, while I explored the hub worlds to get some stud multipliers, what a mistake that turned out to be.Upon finishing my exploration I start and finish the next level, only to find out that my save is now locked before that level, to continue the story I need to begin the level, but the prompt isn't there as I've already completed it.After contacting support and only getting unhelpful generic messages back and 3 months having passed since the issue was reported, I'm still locked, and there is not an ounce of motivation in me to continue or restart, if my save is going to be perma-locked or there's a chance it will happen again.Maybe I'll revisit it once the game has been out for a year and pray it's been fixed, or finally force myself just to restart it.

author: Boyo
review: balls

author: Sage
review: As someone who has played every lego game to date, i am extremely disappointed with the scale, story design, and replay ability. Missions are extremely rushed and can be finished on average in 10mins or less. several major story points are either outright skipped over or given a 20 second cutscene. i was impressed with how space battles and flight now handles, however there is virtually nothing to do in space aside from the few collectables at each planet. cutscenes make up more than half of the of the actual game. That is just an outright terrible decision in my opinion. ethere are zero puzzles, and every collectable can be acquired in the same way on every planet. why. I could barely play through the first six episodes, and that was simply to try and please my inner kid while holding out hope that it would get better as i played. I did not. Graphics do not make a game good, they merely add to the plethora of things needed to create a good game. nothing more needs to be said about that. characters with blaster serve no point aside from using them to get collectables, and they are otherwise unplayable on general occasion because you'll be better of playing with a jedi or other lightsaber wielder, and on that note even they are borderline unplayable because there are hardly in enemies in each mission, i mean like, 10-15, per mission, aside from certain boss battles. oh and about boss battles, they are all the same, i mean full blown copy and paste move sets, and they are not even a threat, because you can sit there and just through your saber at them because 90% of the time they dont know how to block it. Your multiplayer is utter trash and just does not work, I spent an hour with my brother trying to get remote play to work, but we had no luck. Overall I do not recomend getting this game, especially if you want the nostalgia of the older games. At that point, just buy the older games and replay them, because this game brings little to nothing to the table. I'd barely give the game a 3/10.

author: Mellxn
review: Childhood reloaded.

author: John♿
review: This game is the definition of a walking simulator.

author: thetonytones
review: I grew up playing the first lego star wars and the complete saga and absolutely loved them. I played Lego Batman, Lego Lord of the Rings, Lego Indiana Jones, Lego Harry Potter, and Lego Clone Wars. I have not played any of the newer lego games, so I wasn't sure what to expect going into this game.I did not like this game very much. The world is very large and full of things, but none of it actually felt valuable. The missions are very short and void of any of the puzzles or big buildables that made the original games so good. Giant waypoints and arrows ruin the puzzle aspect even more. It feels like the developers focused so hard on the open world that they severely underdeveloped the missions. You can run around and talk to people and get sent on fetch quests, but it all just feels hollow and pointless. All of the characters and locations are really cool and fun to see, but ultimately it feels like most of the magic of the earlier games is gone.Also, there's no online co-op for some reason? That would have been a huge plus for this game.

author: LYNESTAR
review: This is one of the worst LEGO games I have played.What I didn't like:Characters sorted into categories, leaving no unique-ness to each character. What I love about previous LEGO character is that you can unlock certain that can do an assortment of different things. In this game, you pick a single character from each character class and that's it. You can just use those exact same characters for the rest of the game, and sometimes you're forced to use the character in each mission from story mode during certain scenes, TT! MY BROTHERS IN CHRIST! I WANT TO FIGHT GRIEVOUS WITH A CHARACTER OF MY CHOOSING. THAT'S PART OF THE FUN! Yet you can't. Extremely disappoining.Speaking on the story levels, disgustingly disappointed. I genuinely had more fun in TCS. Where you can use fight the villains without being locked into non-free play characters, and the puzzles are unique, fresh and engaging. Most the puzzles in this game are repetitive, there is nothing unique about most of these levels, you will find yourself re-doing tasks from one mission to the next so much. Why is there so many space battles, for each planet, THERE'S NO POINT IF THEY'RE ALL THE SAME! If they're all the same, have it for a few planets, no more no less. These missions aren't even fun.Non-Skippable cut-scenes, even during Free-Play. Never had this issue before, Free Play Missions before even used to just not have them at all, that's preferable and it makes sense. I'm not playing for the story anymore, discard those cut-scenes during free play.What I did like:The open worlds were engaging, large in scope and had unique puzzles and interesting quests, although they could be much and confusing at times.The combat is fun, it's probably an improvement on the mashing button of previous LEGO games, although I can't really say this isn't button mashing. There are some obnoxious parts to the combat, like the fact you can't block the main attacks, (that's the whole point of a block function, right?) Instead having to move out of the way of the attack. To conclude, I want the entire story missions to be revamped in the games to come to include unique puzzles, to be longer than 5 minutes and I'd like to see how characters are used within the games, their abilities, perks and powers to be completely re-done so that each character has a value within themselves, rather than a value as the category they are part of. I'd also like to see a lot more effort put into the story mode, replaying these weren't interesting, I wasn't going back in free play happy to finally be experiencing all the secrets I couldn't find in the story mode, it was a slog. A boring, repetitive, non-skippable cut-scene, unable to use my own characters during fights, slog.
